citeinfo.title: Map of Degree-days >5 degrees C accumulating within the frost-free period across All North America

descript.abstract: Climate surfaces were developed by fitting Hutchinson's thin-plate splines to thirty years of local temperature and precipitation data gathered across All North America. From these surfaces, a map was generated which estimates the normal Degree-days >5 degrees C accumulating within the frost-free period for the contemporary, or current, climate.

procstep.procdesc: Daily data temperature and precipitation data was collected at many stations. This daily data was averaged by month. Monthly data was normalized over a thirty-year time period. Monthly normals are available at https://forest.moscowfsl.wsu.edu/climate/current/

AnuSplin 4.3 software was used to fit continuous spline surfaces to monthly normals. This software can be found here: https://cres.anu.edu.au/outputs/anusplin.php Spline coefficients defining the surfaces can be found on our website. These surfaces represent monthly minimum, avgerage, and maximum temperatures; and cumulative precipitation, as functions of lattitude, longitude, and elevation.

Surfaces were then used generate a grid of monthly temperature and precipitation values based on NOAA Global Land One-km Base Elevation (GLOBE) grid map. GLOBE metadata can be found at https://www.ngdc.noaa.gov/nmmrview/xmls/fgdc.jsp?id=gov.noaa.ngdc:G01180&view=html
Finally, this grid of Degree-days >5 degrees C accumulating within the frost-free period was estimated using a model-based algorithm. The R Code used to generate this grid is available upon request.
